title: Police begin cutting Extinction Rebellion activists out of tents
text:
Police have started cutting Extinction Rebellion activists out of their tents (Picture: Getty – AP)

Extinction Rebellion protesters have been warned they must move or be arrested as police begin cutting campaigners out of their tents in a bid to clear gridlocked parts of the capital.

Hundreds of demonstrators camped out in tents overnight to maintain their stronghold on parts of central London, telling police they were prepared to be taken into custody for failing to comply with orders to move their protest to a single site at Trafalgar Square.

Footage has now emerged of officers dismantling tents while demonstrators sit inside as part of the clear-up operation.

The Met imposed a Section 14 order stipulating that any assembly linked to the group’s ‘Autumn Uprising’ must only take place at Trafalgar Square and the pedestrianised area around Nelson’s Column.

Anyone refusing to move will be arrested, they said.

Police officers remove tents belonging to Extinction Rebellion activists in Westminster (Picture: Getty Images)

Climate change activists are gathering to block access to various government departments (Picture: Getty Images)

Officers began cutting through tents in a bid to clear the blockades (Picture: Getty Images)

Images showed them throwing the tents away (Picture: Getty Images)

Police officers drag a tent past the entrance to Downing Street during clear-up operations (Picture: AP)

Workers clear away tents and accessories from Whitehall (Picture: AP)

Demonstrators are guarded by police as they lie along Whitehall (Picture: AP)

A climate demonstrator is carried past the entrance to Downing Street (Picture: AP)

In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, the Met said any group wishing to continue with their Extinction Rebellion protest ‘must’ go to Trafalgar Square, adding: ‘The condition does not have a time limit.

‘In order to impose this condition, the Met required evidence that serious disruption was being caused to communities in London.

‘The Met believes that this action is necessary in order to prevent the demonstrations from causing serious disruption to the community.

‘Anyone who fails to comply with the condition is liable to arrest and prosecution.’

The Met Police said on Tuesday evening they had arrested 212 people.

They said they had arrested another 319 people on Monday, well over the 122 arrests made on the first day of similar protests last April. It brings the total number arrested so far to 531.

However, Scotland Yard was unable to provide further details on what people were arrested on suspicion of.

It came as Prime Minister Boris Johnson described activists as ‘unco-operative crusties’.
